Award.AwardTitle: EXP: Collaborative Research: A cyber-ensemble of inversion, immersion, collaborative workspaces, query and media-making in mathematics classrooms

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
In this Cyberlearning: Transforming Education EXP project, the PIs focus on designing classrooms as collaborative workspaces and learning how such learning environments can foster learning well. They are addressing these issues in high school mathematics classrooms. Learners view videos and read textbooks as homework to begin to learn new content and to deepen their understanding of material already covered. The classroom is "flipped"; rather than the teacher lecturing, the teacher plays the role of mentor and facilitator as learners work in the classroom at making sense of what they've read or heard, applying what they are learning, and deepening their understanding and capabilities. The hard work of learning is thus done along their peers as collaborators and the teacher available as a mentor. Based on cognitive and socio-cognitive theories of learning, the PIs have designed an ensemble of strategies and technological tools for promoting learning in such an environment. The tools include video for story telling in support of reflection, electronic pen-and-ink, and intelligent-tutoring type systems, but the innovation is in the integration of these tools into an ensemble. Research addresses how such an ensemble of technologies can foster deeply absorbing and effective learning experiences and important dynamics associated with learning when collaborative workspaces are in place in formal classrooms.

Many educators and educational theorists are experimenting with the idea of "flipped classrooms," where learners read or view video lectures outside of class and spend classroom time working on problems together or working on projects, in effect, using classroom time for making sense together of what is being learned, applying what is being learned, deepening understanding, and mastering capabilities. While such an approach holds promise for promoting engagement and learning, little systematic research has been done about how, exactly, to design such learning environments to best promote deep and engaged learning. The PIs in this project address that issue, focusing specifically on students learning high school mathematics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to develop and evaluate an ensemble of strategies and technologies to enable new paradigms for classroom interaction: 1) “collaboration workspaces” permitting teachers and students to see and interact with each other’s work, 2) natural language dialog software to promote question-asking and digital resource access, 3) video creation, editing and mixing tools to permit creation of interactive digital video. The contribution of Boulder Language Technologies (BLT) to the project was the development of a dialog agent which interacts with students to help them find video resources relevant to their questions.

Intellectual Merit

BLT implemented a web-based Natural Language agent. The agent has two interfaces:

  1. The Student Interface allows students to type natural language queries. It returns a list of hyperlinks to videos in the library with a short description of each. Students click on the links to watch the videos.
  2. The Developer Interface allows developers to add new resources to the library by giving a simple natural language description of the content the material would address. The system asks the user a number of questions to help produce the semantic representation used to index the item.

 

The interfaces can be run from standard browsers, and are implemented in Django/Python.

 

Math-oriented semantic frames were created from content descriptions in an initial database of resources. Resources are characterized by semantic frames created from the information entered by the developer. This is similar to techniques used in some question answering systems to provide improved relevance scores. Student queries are processed by a question classifier that predicts the semantic content of the desired answer, for example How do I find the product of expressions that have two terms? would look for resources that have the representation

Type: Procedure

Operation: Multiplication

Theme: Binomials

 

The relevance score for a resource is a function of whether the same entities are filling the same roles as that expected from the query.

 

Semantic frames were created that represent the important entities and relations in the domain (elementary algebra), and grammar patterns created to extract these from the student queries.

The agent returns a list of hyperlinks to relevant resources in the database. The links are sorted by relevance score. While the desired item may not always be first in the list, it is almost always present in the first few.

 

After implementation of the initial version of the agent, BLT conducted research to evaluate techniques to improve the efficiency of entering resources into a database by content developers and to improve robustness in retrieving them for students. 

In the initial version of the agent, it was necessary for the developer to answer a series of questions from the system for it to be able to generate the semantic representation for a resource. In order to reduce the burden on the developer, a new  technique was developed to automatically generate the semantic representation for a resource without having to ask the developer a series of questions. The developer just has to enter a set of natural language statements that describe the content of the video. The same methods are also used to enable more robust parsing of student queries. Revisions to the user interfaces were implemented based on the results of the evaluation and improvements were realized for both interfaces.

Products

The project resulted in:

  1. A natural language agent with web-based interfaces for content developers and students
  2. A set of semantic frames to characterize relevant math content
  3. An improved method for content entry
  4. A labelled database of resources

 

Impact

The work reported provides a mechanism to implement a robust natural language agent that enables students to access a database of resources tailored to their subject matter. This provides an important component to enable new curriculum designs. In particular, it will provide an important asset in implementing a flipped classroom paradigm by helping student find resources to help them prepare for classroom time. It provides an efficient way to enter new content in the library and a robust method for students to access it.
